DOC.brief_summary: A prospective , randomize , double blind study design investigate analgesic efficacy wound infusion use diclofenac ropivacaine follow Cesarean section perform via Pfannenstiel incision .
DOC.detailed_description: Study Objective : To assess analgesic efficacy diclofenac ropivacaine administer via wound infusion . Design : Prospective , randomize , double-blind , placebo-controlled study . Setting : Large referral hospital . Patients : 75 woman recover Cesarean section perform via Pfannenstiel incision . Interventions : On completion surgical procedure , 15 cm 19G infusion catheter ( PAINfusorâ„¢ , Baxter ) place fascia . According computer generate randomization schedule , patient divide one three treatment group ( n = 25 ) . - In Group Control water injection administer . - In Group Ropivacaine 0.2 % ropivacaine administer . - In Group Diclofenac diclofenac ( 300 mg/240 ml water injection ) administer . During first 6 postoperative hour , co-investigator administer `` rescue '' analgesia ( 10 ml bolus infusion drug rescue morphine ) . Thereafter , catheter connect elastometric pump ( LV 10 Infusor , Baxter ) fill either water injection , ropivacaine 0.2 % , diclofenac ( 300 mg/240 ml water injection ) . The fluid administer constant infusion rate ( 10 mL/hr ) . Continuous wound infusion continue subsequent 18 postoperative hour . During 18 hour period , subcutaneous morphine 4 mg administer patient request additional analgesia . Measurements Main Results : The follow parameter assess record : 1 . Demographic data 2 . Surgical milestone ( Anesthetic time , surgical time etc ) . 3 . Incidence fail intrathecal anesthesia 4 . VAS pain every 15 min first 6 postoperative hour 5 . Time first pain ( intrathecal anesthesia VAS > 60 mm ) 6 . Number infusion event ( 10 mL 5 mL ) 7 . Rescue morphine administration first 6 postoperative hour . 8 . Subcutaneous morphine administration subsequent 18 postoperative hour . 9 . VAS pain . 10 . The incidence nausea vomit . 11 . Patient satisfaction 24 hour , postoperatively .
